article.title: Gap junction plasticity as a mechanism to regulate network-wide oscillations

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of neurons are represented by the letter "I" in Figure 1A?
In Figure 1B, which type of neuron shows a resonant peak in the gamma frequency range?
What does the red area labeled "SR" in Figure 1D represent?
What is the main difference in neuronal firing patterns between the AI and SR regimes, as shown in Figure 1I?
choices: AI regime has higher firing rate
SR regime has higher firing rate
SR regime shows bursts of spikes
AI regime shows bursts of spikes

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of plasticity is induced by the bursting protocol shown in Figure 2A?
What does the variable "bi" in Figure 2B represent?
choices: Low-pass filtered spike train of neuron i
Gap junction strength between neuron i and j
External input current to neuron i

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2C, where are the steady-state values of the mean gap junction coupling located for the gLTP with soft bounds?
choices: At the transition between AI and SR regimes

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2F, what is the effect of gap junction plasticity on the activity of read-out neurons in response to a step excitatory drive?
choices: Read-out neurons exhibit transient activity at the onset of the drive)
Read-out neurons only respond to fluctuations in the drive

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the effect of increasing the membrane time constant (τv) of inhibitory neurons on the subthreshold resonance frequency, as shown in Figure 3B?
choices: Has no effect on the resonance frequency
Shifts the resonance frequency to a different frequency band

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the condition for two subnetworks with different resonant frequencies to synchronize their activity, as demonstrated in Figure 3E and 3I?
choices: They need to have identical membrane time constants
They need to receive the same input drive
They need to share a sufficient number of gap junctions)
They need to be coupled by chemical synapses

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3G, what happens to the synchronization between the gamma network (GN) and the slow network (SN) when no gap junctions are shared?
choices: The networks do not synchronize and are out-of-phase
The GN oscillates at the SN frequency
The SN oscillates at the GN frequency

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color scale in Figure 3I represent?
choices: Difference in oscillation frequency between GN and SN
Pearson's correlation between the population activities of GN and SN)
Phase difference between GN and SN

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the initial state of the gamma network (GN) in the simulations shown in Figure 4, panels A-D?
In Figure 4B, when the GN and SN are coupled with static gap junctions, how do their oscillation frequencies compare?
choices: They oscillate at the same frequency)
The GN oscillates at a higher frequency than the SN
The SN oscillates at a higher frequency than the GN

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the effect of gap junction plasticity on the synchronization between the GN and SN, as shown in Figure 4, panels E-H?
choices: Plasticity enhances synchronization and allows the networks to lock in-phase even with a small number of shared gap junctions)
Plasticity has no effect on synchronization
Plasticity only affects synchronization when the initial gap junction strengths are equal

multiple_choice_question.text: Comparing Figure 4D and 4H, what can be concluded about the impact of gap junction plasticity on the correlation between the population activities of the GN and SN?
choices: Plasticity has no effect on correlation
Plasticity only affects correlation for certain values of ∆fres

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 5A, what is the impact of introducing gap junctions between the input-network (IN) and the output-network (ON) on the ON\'s activity?
choices: The ON synchronizes its activity with the IN)
The ON oscillates independently of the IN

multiple_choice_question.text: What mechanism is responsible for information transfer from the IN to the ON, as shown in Figure 5B and 5D?
Figure 5F and 5G demonstrate that information transfer through frequency modulation is limited. What is the main limitation?
What is the effect of gap junction plasticity on the robustness of information transfer to gap junction loss, as shown in Figure 5J and 5K?
choices: Plasticity makes the information transfer more vulnerable to gap junction loss
Plasticity enhances the robustness of information transfer by increasing the strength of the remaining gap junctions)
Plasticity has no effect on the robustness to gap junction loss
Plasticity only affects the robustness for certain input signal characteristics
